thread.title: Tanami Nayler 'tried to run' for her life before she was killed by drunk NZ driver
thread.title_full: Tanami Nayler 'tried to run' for her life before she was killed by drunk NZ driver

author: Jane Lee
title: Tanami Nayler 'tried to run' for her life before she was killed by drunk NZ driver
text:
Tanami Nayler 'tried to run' for her life before she was killed by drunk NZ driver JANE LEE Last updated 18:18, February 22 2017 Facebook 
Tanami Nayler was spending a weekend away in Melbourne. 
A Sydney woman visiting Melbourne for the weekend tried to run for her life moments before a drunk driver hit her at more than 150kmh, throwing her into the next intersection and killing her instantly, a court in Australia has heard. 
Sydney woman Tanami Nayler, 24, was walking to her friend's house, across a pedestrian crossing on the corner of King Street and Hawke Street about 2.15 am, on July 30, 2016, when a car driving about 152 kmh in the 60kmh zone ran a red light and struck her. 
A pre-sentence hearing in the County Court on Wednesday heard that New Zealand national Nicholas Davison, 23, had an estimated blood alcohol level of up to 0.22, more than four times over the legal limit, at the time of the crash. 
Nayler was killed instantly, her body striking a traffic pole and being flung a further 10 metres before coming to a halt in the middle of another intersection. 
READ MORE: * New Zealander charged over fatal Melbourne hit-and-run 
She had arrived in Melbourne for the weekend hours earlier to visit a close friend and celebrate a recent promotion to general manager at a clothing store. 
Prosecutor Jeremy McWilliams said that Nayler was walking just ahead of her friend, on the way to his home. 
Her friend heard her say "Oh my God" when she saw the car and saw her try to run out of its path. 
"But there was no time to avoid being struck," McWilliams said. 
She was killed instantly, with her body striking a traffic pole and being flung a further 10 metres before coming to a halt in the middle of another intersection. Ad Feedback 
Davison had stolen a car from an unmanned Thrifty rental agency near Southern Cross Station minutes before the crash. 
He had been separated from his friends earlier that night after he was repeatedly refused entry to a nightclub. 
He matched a set of keys in the office with the recently returned car and drove away, crashing through a boom gate on the way out. 
After he killed Nayler, he ran past her body and later dumped his clothes. 
Police directing traffic near the crime scene later arrested him for being drunk and wearing just his underwear. 
Nayler's parents and a number of relatives were in court for Davison's pre-sentence hearing. 
Many of the 30 victim impact statements from family and friends were read and a video and photo tribute to Nayler was played to the court. 
Vivien Nayler said her daughter was her best friend and "my world", and had exchanged phone calls or text messages every day before she died. 
Before she died, Tanami had text-messaged her to let her know she had arrived in Melbourne safely and loved her. 
Nayler described her only child as intelligent, artistic and witty. 
Her daughter, she said, had "lived life to the full" and was beautiful "inside and out". 
Nayler said she now lived in a "constant state of misery", with hopes of planning Tanami's possible future wedding and travelling with her now gone. 
While the community lived within a 24-hour news cycle and could forget her, she and her family and friends would mourn her for the rest of their lives. 
The hearing, before Judge Christopher Ryan, continues. - Sydney Morning Herald
